channel.title: IRC Bot - Last updated: 21/05/07
channel.description:
[b]Updated[/b] :)
Added a quote command (@quote) which sends a random Sergeant Johnson quote to the channel (quotes from halo and halo 2). Added kick/ban/mute messages (similar to those that are shown when the @quote command is used) Added Johnson's 'pep talks' from The Pillar of Autumn, Metropolis, and the Regret pep talk.
[hr]
Been a while since I've actually worked on this - anyway, quite an improvement to design this time around. :) Removed a few bugs too.
[hr]
Well, the other one was pretty shit. So I made a new one, which turned out far better. :D
Some of the features include:
[ul][li]Serialized User objects, instead of the string comparison based authentication found in the last bot - Regecks said I had to have it :P[/li] [li]HashMap to store users - makes for fast searching when checking if the person who used a command is a user or not[/li] [li]Users can set up their own greets, which the bot will send to the channel upon them entering[/li] [li]Timed bans and mutes (+b and +q IRC modes) - handy because the ban list in a channel only holds 20 by default[/li] [li]If a nickname that is on a timed ban/mute is unbanned/unmuted early, the timer is canceled[/li] [li]Handler objects are recycled, as they are stored in a HashMap like users - therefore there isn't excessive object creation[/li] [li]Australian made :o[/li][/ul]
I enjoyed making it, so chances are it'll get updated too. :)
EDIT: To make your own User object so you can actually use the bot, just add: [code]new User(YourIrcHostName, 10);[/code] to the Main class' constructor the first time you run the bot. Remove it after that, otherwise it will over-write the one that's there, causing possible loss of a greet message you may set etc.

item.title: IRC Bot - Last updated: 21/05/07
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

It looks really excellent, if you keep up development it may even replace moparisdongs in #mopar (shhh)

After a quick look at the code, it looks very good too, and I have a few suggestions for you. First, instead of hard coding the static values in Main.java, perhaps load them from a configuration file? Properties should help you do that. Secondly, The only thing I didn’t particularly like about your code was the huge list of handlers in InputHandler.java, and I had to think about it for a while to think of a better way to do it. Off the top of my head, I think it would be easy for you to load all of them from a configuration file with Properties too, the conf file would look like this:

join:Join
ban:Ban
unban:UnBan
mute:Mute
unmute:UnMute
part:Part
quit:Quit
say:Say
tempban:TempBan
tempmute:TempMute
op:Op
deop:Deop
adduser:AddUser
removeuser:RemoveUser
kick:Kick
kickban:KickBan
setgreet:SetGreet

The format in this case is “command:ClassName”, you load them all, get the iterator from the properties class, and use ‘Class.forName(“ClassName”)’ to get the class then make instances for the classes, if you do need a copy of InputHandler for each handler (I see you pass it into the constructor) just put another method in the interface to accept the parameter for you, then call it on each one.

I tried to give you a good idea on how to do it without spoonfeeding you code because you seem like the kind of guy who likes to do things for himself, if you need any help just ask.

All in all, very nice.
